title: Missed opportunity on eBay
content:
Dang, I was so close to being the high bidder on this;   
 [http://cgi.ebay.com/ws/eBayISAPI.dll?ViewItem&item=3590214577&category=12570&sspagename=STRK%3AMEBDW%3AIT&rd=1](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516142826/http:/cgi.ebay.com/ws/eBayISAPI.dll?ViewItem&item=3590214577&category=12570&sspagename=STRK%3AMEBDW%3AIT&rd=1)   
(opening bid $9.95)   
but then the serious bidding started.
author: kegler

comments.content: I guess you were hooked by the come-on, "If printing is your thing..."
Richard whats up with your new Star Ucks logo, did they finally do the right thing?
A variety of consonants are awaiting insertion pending resolution.

It's amazing. For this sum I would at least have investigated if there is an alternative.   
   
 [http://www.abebooks.de/servlet/BookDetailsPL?bi=262656236](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516142826/http:/www.abebooks.de/servlet/BookDetailsPL?bi=262656236)

The E-Bay book was a 1848 type specimen book, while Abe Books is offering and 1882 book. Not the same thing, I should think.   
   
T

\> A variety of consonants are awaiting insertion pending resolution.   
   
:-\>   
 [http://www.theonion.com/onion2816/vowels2816.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516142826/http:/www.theonion.com/onion2816/vowels2816.html)   
   
hhp
I was wondering when someone was going to post that Onion story... aren't we due for the "Helvetica sweeps the Fontys" article to be posted? :^)

\> The E-Bay book was a 1848 type specimen book, while Abe Books is offering and 1882 book. Not the same thing, I should think.   
   
yes, of course. but would you pay 2.700 $ for 34 years? I don't think, that there is a such a huge difference between those books.

The book may well be extremely rare and obviously worth that much to at least two parties. It was just a few grand more than I would have considered paying.   
   
I was struck that for a listing of a type specimen book, there was a curious lack of type specimens shown. I am sure the seller was in shock at the final price.

\> a curious lack of type specimens shown.   
   
Makes sense. The people who pay that kind of money are collectors - they have little interest in the content.   
   
hhp
